[File: aptos-core/consensus/src/consensus_provider.rs] [Function: start_consensus()] [Channel overflow] The timeout_sender channel is created with a buffer size of 1,024 messages - can a Byzantine validator flood this channel with malicious timeout messages to cause buffer overflow, dropping legitimate timeouts and causing consensus liveness failures? [File: aptos-core/consensus/src/consensus_provider.rs] [Function: start_consensus()] [Self-message DoS] The self_sender channel is created as unbounded - can this be exploited by malicious code paths to queue unlimited self-messages, causing memory exhaustion and validator node crashes leading to network partition? [File: aptos-core/consensus/src/consensus_provider.rs] [Function: start_consensus()] [Timeout counter manipulation] The PENDING_ROUND_TIMEOUTS counter tracks timeout messages - can integer overflow in this counter be exploited to wrap around and hide timeout flooding attacks from monitoring systems? [File: aptos-core/consensus/src/consensus_provider.rs] [Function: start_consensus()] [Self-message counter bypass] Can the PENDING_SELF_MESSAGES counter be manipulated to underreport the true number of queued self-messages, hiding a self-message flooding attack that exhausts validator memory? [File: aptos-core/consensus/src/consensus_provider.rs] [Function: start_consensus()] [Execution filter bypass] Does the execution_filter from node_config.transaction_filters properly validate all transaction types, or can malicious transactions bypass filtering during ExecutionProxy initialization and execute unauthorized system transactions?
